meanings.def: to add to something in a way that improves it or makes it more attractive
examples: The excellent menu is complemented by a good wine list.
The team needs players who complement each other.
The flavours in the dish complement each other perfectly.
She complimented me on my English.
The different flavours complement each other perfectly.
She made some very complimentary remarks about my English.
There was a complimentary basket of fruit in our room.
The team members have different but complementary skills.

meanings.def: a thing that adds new qualities to something in a way that improves it or makes it more attractive
examples: This vegetable's natural sweetness is a perfect complement to salty or rich foods.

meanings.def: the complete number or quantity needed or allowed
examples: We've taken our full complement of trainees this year.

meanings.def: a word or phrase, especially an adjective or a noun, that is used after linking verbs such as be and become, and describes the subject of the verb. In some descriptions of grammar it is used to refer to any word or phrase that is governed by a verb and usually comes after the verb in a sentence.
examples: In the sentences ‘I'm angry’ and ‘He became a politician’, ‘angry’ and ‘politician’ are complements.
